com.biorecorder.edflib

Class EdfFileWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.biorecorder.edflib.base.EdfWriter
      • com.biorecorder.edflib.EdfFileWriter

  • public class EdfFileWriter
extends EdfWriter
    This class permits to write digital or physical samples from multiple measuring channel to EDF or BDF File. Every channel (signal) has its own sample frequency.

    If the file does not exist it will be created. Already existing file with the same name will be silently overwritten without advance warning!!

    To write data samples to the file we must provide it a HeaderConfig object with the configuration information. Only after that data samples could be written correctly.

    We may write digital or physical samples. Every physical (floating point) sample will be converted to the corresponding digital (int) one using physical maximum, physical minimum, digital maximum and digital minimum of the signal.

    Every digital (int) value will be converted to 2 LITTLE_ENDIAN ordered bytes (16 bits) for EDF files or to 3 LITTLE_ENDIAN ordered bytes (24 bits) for BDF files and in this form written to the file.

    See Also:
    EdfWriter

    • Constructor Detail

      • EdfFileWriter

        public EdfFileWriter(java.io.File file,
                     HeaderConfig headerConfig)
              throws FileNotFoundRuntimeException
        Creates EdfFileWriter to write data samples to the file represented by the specified File object. HeaderConfig object specifies the type of the file (EDF_16BIT or BDF_24BIT) and provides all necessary information for the file header record. A HeaderConfig object must be passed to the EdfFileWriter before writing any data samples. We may do that in the constructor or by method EdfWriter.setConfig(EdfConfig).
        Parameters:
        file - the file to be opened for writing
        headerConfig - object containing all necessary information for the header record
        Throws:
        FileNotFoundRuntimeException - if the file exists but is a directory rather than a regular file, does not exist but cannot be created, or cannot be opened for any other reason

      • EdfFileWriter

        public EdfFileWriter(java.io.File file,
                     FileType fileType)
              throws FileNotFoundRuntimeException
        Creates EdfWriter to write data samples to the file represented by the specified File object. A HeaderConfig object specifying the type of the file (EDF_16BIT or BDF_24BIT) and providing all necessary information for the file header record must be passed to the EdfFileWriter before writing any data samples. Use the method EdfWriter.setConfig(EdfConfig).
        Parameters:
        file - the file to be opened for writing
        fileType - EDF_16BIT or BDF_24BIT
        Throws:
        FileNotFoundRuntimeException - if the file exists but is a directory rather than a regular file, does not exist but cannot be created, or cannot be opened for any other reason

        Returns:
        Edf/Bdf file where this writer writes data

      • setDurationOfDataRecordsComputable

        public void setDurationOfDataRecordsComputable(boolean isComputable)
        If true the average duration of DataRecords during writing process will be calculated and the result will be written to the file header.

        Average duration of DataRecords = (time of coming last DataRecord - time of coming first DataRecord) / total number of DataRecords

        Parameters:
        isComputable - - if true duration of DataRecords will be calculated

      • writePhysicalSamples

        public void writePhysicalSamples(double[] physicalSamples)
                          throws EdfRuntimeException
        Description copied from class: EdfWriter
        Write physical samples (uV, mA, Ohm) from the given array to the stream/file.

        Call this method for every signal (channel) of the stream/file. The order is important! When there are 4 signals, the order of calling this method must be:
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Number of samples (length) for every signal: n_i = (sample frequency of the signal_i) * (duration of DataRecord).

        The entire DataRecord (data pack) containing digital data from all signals also can be placed in one array and written at once.

        The physical samples will be converted to digital samples using the values of physical maximum, physical minimum, digital maximum and digital minimum of of the signal.

        Overrides:
        writePhysicalSamples in class EdfWriter
        Parameters:
        physicalSamples - physical samples belonging to some signal or entire DataRecord
        Throws:
        EdfRuntimeException - if an I/O occurs while writing data to the file

      • writeDigitalSamples

        public void writeDigitalSamples(int[] digitalSamples,
                                int offset,
                                int length)
                         throws EdfRuntimeException,
                                java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Description copied from class: EdfWriter
        Writes «length» digital (integer) samples from the specified array starting at offset «offset» to this EDF/BDF stream/file.

        Call this method for every signal (channel) of the stream/file. The order is important! When there are 4 signals, the order of calling this method must be:
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        samples belonging to signal 0, samples belonging to signal 1, samples belonging to signal 2, samples belonging to signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Number of samples (length) for every signal: n_i = (sample frequency of the signal_i) * (duration of DataRecord).

        The entire DataRecord (data pack) containing digital data from all signals also can be placed in one array and written at once.

        Specified by:
        writeDigitalSamples in class EdfWriter
        Parameters:
        digitalSamples - data array with digital samples
        offset - the start offset in the data.
        length - the number of bytes to write.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if EdfConfig was not set
        EdfRuntimeException - if an I/O occurs while writing data to the file

      • close

        public void close()
           throws EdfRuntimeException
        Description copied from class: EdfWriter
        Closes this Edf/Bdf writer and releases any system resources associated with it. This writer may no longer be used for writing DataRecords. This method MUST be called after finishing writing DataRecords. Failing to do so will cause unnessesary memory usage and corrupted and incomplete data writing.
        Specified by:
        close in class EdfWriter
        Throws:
        EdfRuntimeException - if an I/O occurs while closing the file writer

      • getWritingInfo

        public java.lang.String getWritingInfo()
        Gets some info about file writing process: start recording time, stop recording time, number of written DataRecords, average duration of DataRecords.
        Returns:
        string with some info about writing process

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Unit Test. Usage Example.

        Create the file: current_project_dir/records/test.edf and write to it 10 data records. Then print some file header info and writing info.

        Data records has the following structure:
        duration of data records = 1 sec (default)
        number of channels = 2;
        number of samples from channel 0 in each data record (data package) = 50 (sample frequency 50Hz);
        number of samples from channel 1 in each data record (data package) = 5 (sample frequency 5 Hz);

        Parameters:
        args - the command-line arguments
